Award.AwardTitle: The Influence of Effective Population Size on the Strength of Selection Imposed by Mate Choice
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most intriguing discoveries of the past 20 years of evolutionary genetics is the rapid evolution of some reproductive genes. That genes with such critical roles should functionally diverge over time seems paradoxical. Selection imposed by mate choice may drive some of this functional divergence as individuals continually grapple for reproductive success. This research project focuses on ~10 mouse species that differ in mating system and population size, offering a unique opportunity to predict and test the strength and direction of reproductive selection. The evolution of ~1000 reproductive genes gathered from ~150 individuals across these species will be studied via high throughput sequencing and rigorous computational approaches. This work will significantly advance our understanding of the forces that moderate genetic variation within and between species.

To broaden the impacts of our research, we have engaged students of West Adams, a downtown Los Angeles high school with a typical inner city story. Nearly 30% of students drop out before graduating and more than 50% failed first year biology. However, the teachers are eager to bring alternative strategies into the classroom. Several of their students have already taken "ownership" in specific aspects of this research project and will be co-authors on resulting publications. Immersing high school in all aspects of our research will demystify the scientific process and expose them to new ideas about potential career paths.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported research on the influence of effective population size and mating system on genomic variation. The intellectual merit derives from the fact that in many species, fewer males successfully reproduce compared to females. This leads to an effective skew in the sex ratio that can have dramatic effects on genomic diversity.  Namely, as fewer males reproduce, the amount of diversity on the X chromosome is expected to increase (because there are more females, each of which carries two X chromosomes instead of one). By concentrating on four different species of mice, we learned that this prediction is not always straightforward, and that population demography must be taken into account. There were three specific aims: i) estimate the effective population size of Mus spretus, an important species in the house mouse complex, ii) estimate the number of effectively breeding males and females across four species of mice, and iii) analyzing adaptation in male reproductive genes after taking effective population into account.  All three specific aims have been accomplished, and are either published, in review, or about to be submitted.  The broader impacts is that multiple high school students have participated in this research. These high school students were directly involved in the science, from hypothesis to data collection to analyses and communication of results. In other words, high school students played an integral part of science rather than performing menial lab chores.
